articles.headline: Recession Drains Social Security and Medicare
articles.snippet: The Medicare hospital insurance trust fund may be depleted by 2017 and Social Security reserves gone by 2037, a new report from trustees says.
articles.abstract: The Medicare hospital insurance trust fund may be depleted by 2017 and Social Security reserves gone by 2037, a new report from trustees says.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even as Congress hunted for ways to finance a major expansion of health insurance coverage, the Obama administration reported Tuesday that the financial condition of the two largest federal benefit programs, Medicare and Social Security, had deteriorated, in part because of the recession.

articles.headline: Cargo Ships Treading Water Off Singapore, Waiting for Work
articles.snippet: One of the largest fleets of ships ever gathered idles just off Singapore, marooned by the receding tide of global trade.
articles.abstract: One of the largest fleets of ships ever gathered idles just off Singapore, marooned by the receding tide of global trade.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINGAPORE  To go out in a small boat along Singapore’s coast now is to feel like a mouse tiptoeing through an endless herd of slumbering elephants.

articles.headline: Toyota, Too, Is Looking to Cut Costs
articles.snippet: In a soft market for autos, the carmaker is trying to wring more costs out of its already-lean manufacturing operations.
articles.abstract: In a soft market for autos, the carmaker is trying to wring more costs out of its already-lean manufacturing operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, Ontario  When Toyota opened its newest North American assembly plant here last fall, it was chock full of the company’s very latest thinking and innovations for building a car efficiently.

articles.headline: Mideast’s Christians Losing Numbers and Sway
articles.snippet: The pope this week is addressing a dwindling Christian population driven away by violence, lack of economic opportunity and the rise of radical Islam.
articles.abstract: The pope this week is addressing a dwindling Christian population driven away by violence, lack of economic opportunity and the rise of radical Islam.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  Christians used to be a vital force in the Middle East. They dominated Lebanon and filled top jobs in the Palestinian movement. In Egypt, they were wealthy beyond their number. In Iraq, they packed the universities and professions. Across the region, their orientation was a vital link to the West, a counterpoint to prevailing trends.

articles.headline: Billions Withdrawn Before Madoff Arrest
articles.snippet: About $12 billion was pulled out of accounts at Bernard L. Madoff’s firm in 2008, half of which was taken out in the three months before his arrest.
articles.abstract: About $12 billion was pulled out of accounts at Bernard L. Madoff’s firm in 2008, half of which was taken out in the three months before his arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: About $12 billion was pulled out of accounts at Bernard L. Madoff’s firm in 2008, according to several people briefed on an analysis of Mr. Madoff’s business records.
articles.byline: By Diana B. Henriques and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Unofficial Software Incurs Apple's Wrath
articles.snippet: New applications popping up for Apple's iPhone require a process known as jailbreaking, which Apple says is a copyright violation.
articles.abstract: New applications popping up for Apple's iPhone require a process known as jailbreaking, which Apple says is a copyright violation.
articles.lead_paragraph: The iPhone can teach its users how to perform CPR, show them how to mix a White Russian and allow them to identify any song playing on the radio.

articles.headline: Doctor Falsified Study on Injured G.I.’s, Army Says
articles.snippet: A former Army surgeon who is also a consultant for a medical company has been accused of overstating the benefits of a product used in treating soldiers.
articles.abstract: A former Army surgeon who is also a consultant for a medical company has been accused of overstating the benefits of a product used in treating soldiers.
articles.lead_paragraph: A former surgeon at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, who is a paid consultant for a medical company, published a study that made false claims and overstated the benefits of the company’s product in treating soldiers severely injured in Iraq, the hospital’s commander said Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Duff Wilson and Barry Meier

articles.headline: Stimulus Aid Trickles Out, but States Seek Quicker Relief
articles.snippet: The federal government has paid out less than 6 percent of the $787 billion economic stimulus package, largely in the form of social service payments to states.
articles.abstract: The federal government has paid out less than 6 percent of the $787 billion economic stimulus package, largely in the form of social service payments to states.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly three months after President Obama approved a $787 billion economic stimulus package, intended to create or save jobs, the federal government has paid out less than 6 percent of the money, largely in the form of social service payments to states.

articles.headline: Health Care, a Lesson in Pain
articles.snippet: Providing health insurance to the roughly 50 million Americans without it will cost about $120 billion a year, and the president is far short.
articles.abstract: Providing health insurance to the roughly 50 million Americans without it will cost about $120 billion a year, and the president is far short.
articles.lead_paragraph: The events of the last few weeks have raised the odds that a health care overhaul will really happen this year.

articles.headline: A General Steps From the Shadows
articles.snippet: Lt. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, set to become the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan, is said to move easily between the political and military realms.
articles.abstract: Lt. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, set to become the top U.S. commander in Afghanistan, is said to move easily between the political and military realms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Lt. Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal, the ascetic who is set to become the new top American commander in Afghanistan, usually eats just one meal a day, in the evening, to avoid sluggishness.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Mark Mazzetti
